user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_SelectMultiple:
```c
int32 OS_SelectMultiple(OS_FdSet *ReadSet, OS_FdSet *WriteSet, int32 msecs)
{
    int32 return_code;

    /*
     * Check parameters
     *
     * Note "ReadSet" and "WriteSet" are not checked, because in certain configurations they can be validly null.
     */

    /*
     * This does not currently increment any refcounts.
     * That means a file/socket can be closed while actively inside a
     * OS_SelectMultiple() call in another thread.
     */
    return_code = OS_SelectMultiple_Impl(ReadSet, WriteSet, msecs);

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: Other parts of the function do not contain pointer declarations or uses that could be considered for const-qualification: - There are no other pointer parameters or local pointer variables in this function. - Scalar locals/parameters (return_code, msecs) are not pointer types. - The body contains only a call to the implementation and a return; there is no pointer arithmetic, casts, or assignments that would implicate const-qualification. - Comments and control flow are not relevant to Rule 8.13. Therefore only the pointer-bearing function signature and the pass-through call (which expose the pointer parameters) need to be investigated for possible const qualification.
